posts.post_content:
I just \*love\* the synergy of this card with both scavenge and evolve from the most recent block. Nice to see those mechanics getting backed up in the following core set.  
  
After Thragtusk rotates out this guy definitely has a chance at the 5 mana slot, given that on his first swing he's an 8/8 for 5 with pseudo-evasion that can give you even more power if you have any other creatures with counters.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
[Exava](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Exava) into this is pretty good.  
  
Let's dream:  
T1 [Elvish Mystic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Elvish Mystic)  
T3 [Exava, Rakdos Blood Witch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Exava, Rakdos Blood Witch) unleashed  
T4 [Kalonian Hydra](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kalonian Hydra), attack for 13 (Exava has 2 counters and is a 5/5, Hydra is 8/8)  
T5 Kalonian Hydra, two triggers, everything has counters quadrupled  
Exava has 8 counters and is an 11/11  
#1 Hydra is 32/32, #2 Hydra is 16/16  
Attack for 59 damage, most of it with trample

posts.post_content:
Scary card. Great in limited, but i feel we've reached a point in standard history where a 5 drop should make an impact on the game the moment it enters the battlefield. It sucks to feel that way, but its the way of games overtime. Look at [Thundermaw Hellkite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thundermaw Hellkite). [Thragtusk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thragtusk)  
  
I'm scared to play him, and for him to get [Doom Blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom Blade)d. Prolly run a few other threats before hand, make sure your opponent has used up all his/her removal.  
Can't wait to end of opponents turn, [Savage Summoning](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Savage Summoning) this, next turn attack for 10/10 trample, pumping up my other evolve creatures or what not.

Posted By: link3343 (7/10/2013 11:36:59 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I think this guy's got a shot at standard play. As everyone's said, your five drops need to do something when they hit the board, and this guy doesn't. However, with something like [Exava, Rakdos Blood Witch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Exava, Rakdos Blood Witch) on the field or end of turn [Savage Summoning](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Savage Summoning), this guy could provide quite the beating. Even so, this is a card that must be answered immediately.  
  
Regardless, this is a limited super bomb and will probably be a casual favorite for a long time.
posts.html:
I think this guy's got a shot at standard play. As everyone's said, your five drops need to do something when they hit the board, and this guy doesn't. However, with something like Exava, Rakdos Blood Witch on the field or end of turn Savage Summoning, this guy could provide quite the beating. Even so, this is a card that must be answered immediately.

Regardless, this is a limited super bomb and will probably be a casual favorite for a long time.

Posted By: The_Trendkill (7/11/2013 7:17:31 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Strange how well ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) plays with ![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) considering they're "enemy colors". Between them, there's plenty of +1/+1 counter synergy to go around. And bounce in ![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) goes very well with trample in ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) - bounce a blocker, and Kalonian Hydra can deal all its damage to the opponent.  
And on top of that, the art is spectacular and really evokes a *massive* creature. Fantastic big creature, and a worthy addition to Green's signature tribe. Will never see Standard play, but I'm certainly going to pick up a few.
posts.html:
Strange how well plays with considering they're "enemy colors". Between them, there's plenty of +1/+1 counter synergy to go around. And bounce in goes very well with trample in - bounce a blocker, and Kalonian Hydra can deal all its damage to the opponent.
And on top of that, the art is spectacular and really evokes a massive creature. Fantastic big creature, and a worthy addition to Green's signature tribe. Will never see Standard play, but I'm certainly going to pick up a few.

posts.post_content: I'm not quite sure how, but i managed to beat kalonian hydra and its clone. By my turn 5 my opponent has played nothing while i have been slowly working my way through his life points and managed to get him down to 8 via the new 3/3 for GG. Opponent's T5 hydra stops me cold. Opponent's T6 clone, copying hydra, swing with first hydra making both himself and the clone 8/8s. Lucky me had a celestial flare for that one. But i still can't swing back and i have no more kill cards in hand. But i do have a 5/5 groundshaker sliver to drop. T7 the clone rumbles in as a 16/16 and drops me straight from 20 to 4; then he drops a blocker in front of my exactly lethal on the board creature presence. My turn i get bone lucky and rip the new fight card (hunt the weak) off the top of my library, neutralize his blocker, and swing in for game on the one turn i have before a 32/32 trampler squishes me.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
What makes this any better than Wolfir Silverheart?  
  
- They are both 3GG and have a base of 4/4.  
  
- Without any special synergy or help (aside from just having a random creature in play), Wolfir becomes an 8/8 while the hydra needs to attack once before it gets to 8/8.   
  
- Wolfir immediately gives one of your other creatures +4/+4 with the only restriction being that it cannot be paired before Wolfir etb's, while the Hydra only interacts with +1/+1 counters. This also allows the paired creature with Wolfir to swing with the buff right after wolfir etb's.  
  
While it's true that the hydra is better with haste, has innate trample, will become much bigger than Wolfir if it attacks twice, and can potentially buff a lot more creatures than Wolfir can, Wolfir is more reliable (it doesn't need any special cards or help to function other than just having random creatures out), is better when you are on the defensive (when it etb's if it soulbonds with another creature you put 12 extra power on t... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
What makes this any better than Wolfir Silverheart?

- They are both 3GG and have a base of 4/4.

- Without any special synergy or help (aside from just having a random creature in play), Wolfir becomes an 8/8 while the hydra needs to attack once before it gets to 8/8.

- Wolfir immediately gives one of your other creatures +4/+4 with the only restriction being that it cannot be paired before Wolfir etb's, while the Hydra only interacts with +1/+1 counters. This also allows the paired creature with Wolfir to swing with the buff right after wolfir etb's.

While it's true that the hydra is better with haste, has innate trample, will become much bigger than Wolfir if it attacks twice, and can potentially buff a lot more creatures than Wolfir can, Wolfir is more reliable (it doesn't need any special cards or help to function other than just having random creatures out), is better when you are on the defensive (when it etb's if it soulbonds with another creature you put 12 extra power on t... posts.post_content:
Unless im missing something [dreadbore](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=dreadbore), [Doomblade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doomblade), [Selesnya Charm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Selesnya Charm)(after it has its counters) and deathtouch are the only ways to deal with this effectively in standard.  
  
It may not have the ability's of some other cards but other then the above mentioned cards and ability if this gets to attack even once it is most likely going to win you the game.
